People always ask me what it was like and I always refer them to look for things on the internet to get some perspective.  Things have changed a lot since back then.  We did 6 hour watches when fully staffed and sometimes had to do 9 hour or 12 hour depending on situation.  Drills were part of the process as the fire but their drill seemed minor compared to ours as everyone had to get up and get going.  It was all in getting breathing protection out(which by the way, certainly tests EVERY piece of equipment) and knowing where to be and what you were doing.  FYI...they have a bigger crews mess than we did.  We did not have a "buffet" table LOL. But all in all this video series will give everyone that asks me as I refer to this what it's like being on a sub.  The space is limited and there is equipment everywhere.  Thanks again.

Fixing pipes in a submerged submarine in the Arctic sounds like one of the fiddliest thing you could be made to do under the worst conditions. The closest i've come to anything like that is either sailor survival training in Icelandic sea in December, or adjusting a signal transmitter in Icelandic winter in freezing winds, and we're smack dab in the middle of the Gulf stream, so while we are technically Arctic i think, we've got much milder temperatures than the waters they're sailing in. I'd just beg that numbness happened soon so that i wouldn't feel like i'm on fire (FYI you from warmer climes, working bare handed  in freezing temps can feel like you peeled the top layer of skin off your hand and stuck it into pure alcohol. And DO NOT put your hands  in warm or hot water to warm up.  That's like subsequently lighting that alcohol soaked wound on fire). When in freezing water, your body also freaks out, and you can completely lose control of your breathing, so you better keep your head above water for as much of it as you can. Good thing that those tools aren't fiddly. Hat's off to these gentlemen.

I will try to keep this answer fairly non-technical, but there’s some pretty cool science going on here…

We monitor and control the atmosphere pretty closely on submarines, as you might imagine. This is a simplification, but we are worried mostly about CO2 (we don’t want it to get too high) and O2 (we don’t want it to get too low).

For fire to burn, the oxygen percentage needs to be above about 16% (sea level is about 21% oxygen). On submarines, we have a huge incentive to make it difficult for fires to burn, so we wanted to keep oxygen percentage as low as possible.

However, what your lungs care about is the “partial pressure” of oxygen. Partial pressure is the pressure attributable to the fraction of the gas in question, so it’s a function both of percentage and pressure. You can actually suffocate breathing pure O2 if the pressure is low enough, like at high altitudes - this is what’s so hard about climbing Everest - climbers can’t get enough O2, even though they are breathing pure O2, because the total pressure and partial pressure of O2 is too low.

At sea level, where the atmospheric pressure is 760 mm of mercury, the “partial pressure” of oxygen is 160mm of Hg (21% of 760). If I recall correctly, the atmosphere monitoring system on my submarine listed 140–160 as the desired range for O2 partial pressure.

In order to reduce the percentage of O2 (to reduce risk of fire) but keep the partial pressure of O2 within the normal range, what we would do as Officer of the Deck (OOD) is to increase the pressure inside the sub by about 10%, while maintaining the partial pressure of O2 right at the lower limit. So, for example, if we were at 860 mmHg of total atmospheric pressure instead of 760mmHg, and at 140mmHg O2, the percentage of O2 would be only 16.3% - and it would be really hard to light cigarettes. Did the O2 partial pressure drop below 140, further reducing the O2 percentage so cigarettes wouldn’t light? Occasionally? Sometimes it would liven up a boring midwatch to have an irate smoker storm up to the control room and complain about not being able to smoke.

Since I was in the Navy when smoking was allowed onboard, we tried to maintain a balance where a cigarette would burn, just not very well, to limit the risk of large fires. A good chunk of the crew couldn’t totally wrap their head around the idea that they could still breathe even if a fire wouldn’t burn, which created all kinds of psychosomatic symptoms that folks would complain about.

I'm a former USN serviceman, albeit aboard an aircraft carrier. I honestly love these deep dives as they provide me with a ton of nostalgia but more importantly, you give such a genuine reaction WRT how interesting these seemingly mundane topics can be when put in the context of being onboard a warship. I remember the first time I stepped aboard the USS George HW Bush...it was awe inspiring. I remember vividly the first time I felt the reverberations in my chest while witnessing a jet firing it's afterburner on the flight deck after being captured by arresting gear, so primal in it's savagery. The feeling of being launched in a COB(carrier onboard delivery plane) to ready shore power is one of the most viscerally exciting experiences I've ever lived through.

But the things I remember most are the interactions with the crew and the seemingly meaningless day to day bits that define life aboard a warship. From the red lights during the evening, to the trips to the smoke deck during the day. Drills were a part of that, and while they are certainly not my favorite memories aboard the ship, they're present nonetheless and you've done a good job of capturing just how interesting they can be from an outsider's perspective.

Edit: Fun fact for anyone watching. The thing on the senior chief's(Matt Charlton's) belt is called a TLD or Thermo luminescent Dosimeter. It's the device that the navy uses to track exposure to nuclear radiation for those that work in the reactor division aboard a ship. He is the leading enlisted member of the reactor controls division(RC Div) aboard the submarine and is an E8, or senior chief, the second highest rank among enlisted personnel in the USN. RC div is the division that actually mans the reactor control panel on a submarine. They control the nuclear reactor that powers the ship. You go through at least 1 and a 1/2 years of training to become a nuclear operator aboard a navy vessel, more if you're aboard a submarine, not including boot camp.

Count the water tight compartments. We won't count the spherical sonar array in the bow. Consider the volume of each compartment, with the engine room being the largest, and the torpedo room being the smallest. Now guess which compartments can be fully flooded and still recover the ship.
Now ask yourself which compartment has the highest number of seawater penetrations, on an attack boat. Yep, the engine room. The biggest one of all is the penetration where the propulsion shaft penetrates the hull, but there are many large diameter holes in the hull to allow for the circulation of seawater to be used in the main condensers and for auxiliary cooling systems. Then remember that, even with all those big hull penetrations, the engine room can't be completely flooded and have the ship retain enough positive buoyancy to recover the boat even if the main ballast tanks are blown and the trim tanks emptied.
Remember that the next time you read or think about US submariners roaming out there on your behalf. It's never a picnic and there is always going to be at least one episode of pure terror per patrol, just because of the nature of the ship.

I served on an Ohio class submarine in the late 90's / early 2000's. The one thing that stood out to me was the mention of the 8-hour watches; when I was in we did 6-hour ones. With that said, how do the meals work time-wise? We had breakfast @ 5AM, lunch @ 11AM, dinner @ 5PM, and midrats @ 11PM (if I remember right).

Our drill sets used to happen daily on the 1200-1800 watch with multiple drills per set. This somewhat ensured that you hit on-watch, off-going, and on-coming positions with respect to your response through the week. No drills on Saturday (usually) or Sunday for us, but Field Day (cleaning the ship) usually took place on the Saturday 0600-1200 watch. Sometimes a drill was used to get everyone awake and it looked like CAMS had a nice jacked-up oxygen level, lol.

Talk about having double & triple checks already in place, constantly enforced & followed through with, always. That way, even IF there would be someone who panics OR in that panic, perhaps forgets something... there is always a system in place to keep that handled properly. Already covered, as a means to protect ALL Furthermore, noticed it right away..... You know training was proper, authority, rules/guidelines, procedure followed + overall compassion & integrity SO respected. Noticed watching, just how long those guys sat there in those hot suits WITHOUT uttering A WORD & without just assuming or making any decisions, etc.. once the all-clear was given. Why would they still sit there, eyes on the fire, extinguisher aimed & them, STILL on-task? Even w/ the 'all clear'? Well, because as can be seen a bit after.... the one talking, giving orders etc.. had been explaining to camera & forgot to specifically give them their final all clear & dismissal. Once & only when that tap signal & relief come, did they move a muscle, stop what they were doing & exit, as trained. Huge thumbs up to them all, it was quite AMAZING to witness, imho.

Nice to see things, somewhere, running as it should be. Most importantly.. sacrificing &/or it being a given to consider & be there for the well-being of others; often times, having each others lives literally.... in each others hands. What depends upon each doing whatever is necessary... to make sure everything & everyone is ON POINT, at their best, so they can all do their jobs & get home, safely! Rules, procedures, actual enforcement of, issuing accountability & tangible consequences... = making those w/ compassion, integrity behaving properly... the example of how to be. The example of success. All, leading to more & more following of, fear of consequence/loss 'if'... good behavior, more doing right thing to gain rewards.. = more compassion & integrity in this World, which is desperately needed. Those traits + having respect for authority, rules, boundaries, social norms & others should be the norm, not the rare gems they've become. If you don't have those things & bad behavior & "anything goes" continues to be allowed, looked past, presented as examples of 'success' ... even many, greatly rewarded... the chaos, violence, selfishness & narcissism & 'anything goes' as long as its at someone ELSE'S expense, will only continue to keep getting worse imho. These guys, the procedures.. their dedication & respect for all/each other.. Their emotional maturity, level of critical thinking & cognitive reasoning skills & understanding of how it HAS to be, all... refreshing! Destin, what I love. What I really love about this little video is the idea of being a true community. Any moment, without warning, your life may literally depend on the asshat up front knowing exactly how connect a fire hose under pressure or any other thing... or worse, it may depend on YOU knowing exactly how to do something. So you drill it and you make sure everyone does it.

So many lessons there. In so many other "emergency training" scenarios the idea is totally flipped. It's someone else's job to know and maybe, hopefully, they have been trained at some point in the past few months.

I see this and I wish our society, our laws, our lives were so intertwined that we were as interested in the success of our fellow human being. That level of caring brings about a community that -- while it must have its problems -- you can trust to keep your butt safe.

Wow. So many vivid memories immediately come back. Muscle memory they drilled into us?

Flooding. It's interesting to see they're still using all of the same stuff to patch a pipe in a flooding. I remember when we did the wet trainer in submarine school, by the time we were done we had water well up above the deck plates and literally up to our necks. We were actually doing pretty good until they let the ASW flange go, and then it quickly went downhill.

Fire. Although we didn't have bunker gear, SCBA's, or thermal imaging devices. Instead of bunker gear we just had our poopie suits (the blue coveralls they're all wearing) where we had to button and flip up our collars, roll our sleeves down, and tuck our pant legs into our socks (never understood what any of that was supposed to do to protect us). And instead of SCBA's we had OBA's (Oxygen Breathing Apparatus) which oddly enough, the canisters that produced the oxygen could explode when exposed to saltwater... and firefighting water is - saltwater. LOL
These guys don’t skip a beat. Practice practice practice makes perfect!
And here we also get to see one of the most important pieces of equipment aboard a US Navy Sub: The coffee maker.

one thing not covered in this video is where the firefighting water comes from. The ship has a number of auxiliary trim tanks for adjusting ballast. When a fire breaks out, the chief of the watch pressurizes the nearest aux tank to the fire, and that supplies water to the hose. That way, you can fight the fire while minimizing the impact on ship's list and trim. Once water starts building up in the bilges, the chief of the watch can line up the drain pump to suck the water out of the bilge and put it back in the aux tank, essentially recirculating the firefighting water until the fire is out.

So when it comes to sleeping in a submarine, it takes a particular person to do it right and be able to do their duties at any time.  You can't sleep too deep, or you might not wake up in time should a fire start.  But you also can't use any sleep aids for the same reason.  Talk about tough, and these guys have to do it three times a day, every day.  I have much more newfound respect now, not that I, the grandson of a Navy Lieutenant Commander Fire Control Officer, didn't already have respect for them all.  No way I could do this, so I'm thankful that these men, who can do this, are willing to put themselves through this in order to help protect the nation and our freedoms.

Fun fact. Water used for fire fighting is already inside the ship's trim tanks and accounted for in neutral buoyancy. So the fire hose spraying moves water around from an area of the sub to a different area. Therefore, the sub stays neutral buoyant during a fire.

One of the most impressive things I've seen was the Emergency training room at the Submarine Academy in Florida. They had this super cool room that they could completely flood to simulate the inside of a submarine with pipes, hull, walls/floor etc. They could simulate a broken pipe with water shooting out of it and flood the entire room completely up to the ceiling so they could train every simulated emergency situation. Imagine trying to fix a broken hull on a submarine and being completely underwater swimming around trying to fix the hole. It's such an insane environment to try and solve problems in but it was truly impressive mechanically. They could rotate the room on hydraulics and shift the X and Y positions to simulate the submarine nose diving or rolling. it was so incredible.
edit: Ooooooooohhhhh cool!!! They just talked about it around 13:00

They didn't simulate moving the patch over the leak while it is under tension.  I think their simulation is possibly ineffective to how much trouble they will see in getting the patch in place with stinging freezing water in their eyes and the short time their muscles are going to function.  The patch needs a vertical rib to hammer with the friction of the gasket under pressure and the force of incoming water.  I would have them practice while blindfolded, too.     The water will either be toward them, or splashing forcefully off the hull in their face.  Patching tools should be on a belt that you put on.  The boat could be listing and the lights could be out.  With a patching toolbelt, you can find what you need with your hands while blinded by spray or in the dark.

When I was fresh to the fleet, I attended the flood trainer at sub school in Groton, CT 3 days before I was flying home to Florida to be married. I and my team were patching a flooding pipe - I was standing behind my shipmate (who was taking the brunt of the force from the flooding), when he shifted his body without warning and exposed my face directly to the pressure. I turned my head and the force pushed my head from behind and knocked my face right into a stair directly behind me. The bridge of my nose scraped along the non-skid tape on that step and I broke my nose. We got the job done while I bled all over the place (understanding the importance of casualty repair and recovery) -- Many lessons learned. It took a lot of makeup to get my nose into shape for my wedding - but my bride to be was not happy when she saw me getting off the plane. In the end, everything worked out.

My buddy was on a carrier, I was on a sub. The difference is, on a carrier you will never meet all your shipmates, but on a sub each and every one of them is your brother. If a casualty occurs, no matter how small, everyone is involved. The flooding trainer in New London is amazing.....

An interesting thing to note, and I know this because I am a commercial captain licensed by both the U.S. and Panama, that all passenger ships in the U.S. and most any other country that complies with international maritime laws, must pass fire drills during yearly inspections, and MUST, by law, practice fire drills no less than once a week. Firefighter from germany here. The way the firefighting team operates (that the one with the thermal imageing camera taps the hose operator on the shoulder to signal where he should spray) is actually not a really good idea. The way heat protecting clothes work is that you have many different layers of nomex and hydrophobic material with an isolating layer of air between each material layer. When you´re extinguishing a fire in front of you, the outermost layer will be extremely hot. If now someone comes along and taps you on the shoulder, the air will be displaced and all the different layers touch each other. The result is that the insulating effect will be lost and you will get a big burnmark in the form of a hand on your shoulder. Have had this already sometimes but not really bad, because all respirator carriers are told of this effect and will try to comunicate in different ways (like shake on your respirator flasks, in ear radio or something) than to touch you directly.
